relationships.notes: Receives fuller instruction in Ephesus from Priscilla, who helps complete his understanding of the way of God.
Along with Priscilla, Aquila corrects and commissions Apollos for more accurate public ministry.
Shares planting and watering labor with Paul among the Corinthians, prompting Paul to address factionalism that misuses their names.
Mentioned alongside Titus’s charge to equip traveling ministers, implying cooperation with his network.

traits.origin_and_education: Described as a Jew from Alexandria, eloquent and well-versed in the Scriptures.
traits.knowledge_of_johns_baptism: Knows only the baptism of John yet teaches accurately the things concerning Jesus up to that point.
traits.instruction_by_priscilla_and_aquila: Priscilla and Aquila take him aside and explain the way of God more accurately, further equipping him for ministry.
traits.ministry_in_achaia: Ministers in Achaia, greatly helping believers through grace and vigorously refuting opponents in public debate.
traits.scriptural_argumentation: Demonstrates from the Scriptures that the Messiah is Jesus, showing both rhetorical skill and exegetical competence.

traits.co_worker_status: Appears in 1 Corinthians as a fellow worker whose ministry complements Paul’s planting work among the Corinthians.
traits.factional_loyalties: Becomes a focal name in community factions where some claim allegiance to Paul, Apollos, or Cephas, prompting Paul to reject personality cults.
traits.servant_identity: Paul presents both himself and Apollos as servants through whom the Corinthians came to faith, emphasizing God as the one who gives growth.
traits.relationship_with_paul: Paul urges the community not to pit him against Apollos and notes Apollos’s own judgment about when to visit, implying mutual respect and independence.

traits.later_travel_notice: Mentioned with Zenas the lawyer as someone to be sent on their way with all they need, indicating ongoing itinerant ministry.
traits.role_in_church_networks: Appears within a network of coworkers and emissaries who help organize and strengthen emerging communities.
traits.critical_note: This reference occurs in a letter often regarded by critical scholarship as post-Pauline, reflecting later tradition about Apollos’s movements.
